author: @ramanujrai8662
text: 00:01 This video is an introduction to the Intermediate SQL series. 01:43 Performing an inner join to combine similar data based on the employee ID. 04:03 Full outer join shows all data from both tables regardless of a match 06:04 Understanding Left and Right Outer Joins 07:51 Understanding Inner and Outer Joins in SQL 09:55 Exploring inner and outer joins in SQL. 11:51 Understanding inner and outer joins in SQL 14:02 Angela calculates average salary for salesmen using SQL. Crafted by Merlin AI.

Please and thank you!

text: To practice   create table EmployeeDemographics(  EMployeeID int,  FirstName nvarchar(50),  LastName  nvarchar(50),  Age int,  Gender  nvarchar(50) )  create table EmployeeSalary(  EmployeeID int,  JobTitle nvarchar(50),  Salary int )  Insert into EmployeeDemographics VALUES (1001, 'Jim', 'Halpet', 30, 'Male'), (1002, 'Pam','Basley', 30, 'Female'), (1003, 'Dwinght', 'Scchute', 29, 'Male'), (1004, 'Angela', 'Martin', 31, 'Female'), (1005, 'Toby', 'Flenderson', 32, 'Male'), (1006, 'Michaal', 'Scoot', 35, 'Male'), (1007, 'Meredith', 'Palmer', 32, 'Female'), (1008, 'Stanley', 'Hhudson', 38, 'Male'), (1009, 'Kevin', 'Malone', 31, 'Male'), (1011, 'Ryan', 'Howard', 26, 'Male'), (NULL, 'Holly','Flax', NULL, 'Male'), (1013, 'Darryl', 'Philbin', NULL, 'Male')    Insert into EmployeeSalary VALUES (1001, 'Salesman', 45000), (1002, 'Receptionist',36000), (1003, 'Salesman', 63000), (1004, 'Accountant', 47000), (1005, 'HR',50000), (1006, 'Religional',65000), (1007, 'Supplier Receptionist', 41000), (1008, 'Salesman',48000), (1009, 'Accountant', 42000), (1010, NULL, 47000), (NULL, 'Salesman', 43000)

author: @virpat2012
text: For anyone trying to use OUTER JOIN on MySQL:  SELECT * FROM employeedemographics LEFT JOIN employeesalary 	ON employeedemographics.EmployeeID = employeesalary.EmployeeID UNION SELECT * FROM employeedemographics RIGHT JOIN employeesalary 	ON employeedemographics.EmployeeID = employeesalary.EmployeeID

author: @rockymarquiss8327
text: Other databases have an exception join - I don't see that in MS SQL. An Exception join returns data that ONLY exists in one table.  Arguably this can be accomplished in the where clause of an outer join - testing for the keys of the secondary table being null but having it part of the join clause is cleaner. Am I missing something and it exists and not seeing it? For example:  select * from OWNER CUROWN left exception join NEWOWNER newown on CUROWN.OWNERID = NEWOWN.OWNERID would produce rows in the OWNER table that DOES NOT have any data in NEWOWNER.   This can be simulated by: select * from OWNER CUROWN left outer join NEWOWNER newown on CUROWN.OWNERID = NEWOWN.OWNERID where NEWOWN.OWNERID is null  But if you have multiple conditions in the ON clause you have to test that EACH key is null.   In this example it returns values where the owners have not changed.

author: @rondraughon5572
text: If you'd like to shorten your code so you don't have to write EmployeeDemographics or EmployeeSalary every time for everything, you can use an alias by adding ed (for EmployeeDemographics) after EmployeeDemographics in the FROM cluase and es (for EmployeeSalary) after EmployeeSalary in the JOIN clause. Your code for the RIGHT JOIN where you have 5 columns selected would look like this:    SELECT ed.EmployeeID, ed.FirstName, ed.LastName, es.JobTitle, es.Salary FROM EmployeeDemographics ed RIGHT OUTER JOIN EmployeeSalary es          ON ed.EmployeeID = es.EmployeeID  INSTEAD OF THIS  SELECT EmployeeDemographics.EmployeeID, EmployeeDemographics.FirstName, EmployeeDemographics.LastName, EmployeeSalary.JobTitle, EmployeeSalary.Salary FROM EmployeeDemographics  RIGHT JOIN EmployeeSalary          ON EmployeeDemographics.EmployeeID = EmployeeSalary.EmployeeID  Much easier, don't you think?

author: @quentinmcteer5993
text: Love your videos! However, in the final section here finding the average salary of a salesman you used an inner join which eliminated the salesman salary from the employeesalary table because it didn't have an employee ID. By not including the value (NULL, Salesman, 43000) , it skewed the average salesman salary by only evaluating those salesmen with matching employee ID's from both tables. Value should be 49750 not 52000 and you should have used a FULL OUTER JOIN instead.

text: 5:00 full outer join joins from both tables (all rows from left table and all rows from right table, even if they don‚Äôt have a match in the other table, the columns are filled with nulls)  Left outer join: return everything from left table, even when it doesn‚Äôt have match in right table, nulls are returned for the columns
